text: What age verification mechanism is in place to identify minor users?

options.label: Self-declaration
options.description: User states their age (e.g., date of birth field)

options.label: ID verification
options.description: Age verified through government ID or similar document

options.label: Parental confirmation
options.description: Parent or guardian confirms the minor's age

options.label: Age estimation
options.description: Technical methods to estimate age (e.g., facial analysis)

options.label: None
options.description: No age verification mechanism is in place

regulatoryRelevance: COPPA requires verifiable parental consent for children under 13. UK Age Appropriate Design Code requires age assurance. GDPR Article 8 sets consent age for information society services.

text: Is verifiable parental or guardian consent obtained before collecting personal data from minors?
regulatoryRelevance: COPPA requires verifiable parental consent for children under 13. GDPR Article 8 requires parental consent for children below the applicable age (13-16 depending on member state).

text: Are data collection and processing practices limited or modified when the user is identified as a minor?
regulatoryRelevance: UK Age Appropriate Design Code requires data minimization for children. COPPA limits data collection to what is necessary. California AADC requires DPIAs for products likely used by children.

text: Does the system profile, track, or target minors based on their behavior or characteristics?
regulatoryRelevance: UK Age Appropriate Design Code prohibits profiling children by default. GDPR Recital 71 discourages automated decisions about children. California AADC restricts profiling of minors.

text: Has the system been designed with age-appropriate considerations (e.g., simplified interfaces, restricted features, default privacy settings)?
regulatoryRelevance: UK Age Appropriate Design Code requires 15 standards for children's online services. California AADC requires age-appropriate design for products likely accessed by children.
